articles.headline: Resignations Roil Twitter as Elon Musk Tries Persuading Some Workers to Stay
articles.snippet: Mr. Musk, Twitter’s new owner, had given employees a Thursday deadline to decide whether to leave or stay “to build a breakthrough Twitter 2.0.”
articles.abstract: Mr. Musk, Twitter’s new owner, had given employees a Thursday deadline to decide whether to leave or stay “to build a breakthrough Twitter 2.0.”
articles.lead_paragraph: The World Cup usually brings a surge of traffic to Twitter, and that is expected again as the tournament starts this weekend.
articles.byline: By Ryan Mac, Mike Isaac and David McCabe

articles.headline: Biden Administration Offers New Path to Discharging Student Debt in Bankruptcy
articles.snippet: The Justice and Education Departments said the process would be more fair and consistent for people in bankruptcy seeking relief on their federal student loans.
articles.abstract: The Justice and Education Departments said the process would be more fair and consistent for people in bankruptcy seeking relief on their federal student loans.
articles.lead_paragraph: As President Biden’s broad plan to cancel student debt for millions of borrowers faces mounting legal challenges, his administration took a separate step that could make it easier for the most vulnerable student borrowers to clear their debts: through bankruptcy.

articles.headline: Will Taxing the Windfall Profits of Oil Giants Fix Countries’ Economies?
articles.snippet: Britain is raising a tax on gas and oil producers, and adding a levy on companies that supply electricity — a similar approach to that of other governments chasing revenue.
articles.abstract: Britain is raising a tax on gas and oil producers, and adding a levy on companies that supply electricity — a similar approach to that of other governments chasing revenue.
articles.lead_paragraph: Major oil and gas companies have raked in multibillion-dollar profits at unheard-of levels. Households around the world are reeling from soaring energy prices, while governments are struggling with outsize spending and slowing economic growth.

articles.headline: U.S. Backs Immunity for Saudi Leader in Lawsuit Over Khashoggi Murder
articles.snippet: The State Department said Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, the kingdom’s de facto ruler, should have legal immunity as the head of the Saudi government.
articles.abstract: The State Department said Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, the kingdom’s de facto ruler, should have legal immunity as the head of the Saudi government.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — The Biden administration has declared that Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia should be granted immunity in a U.S. legal case over his role in the murder of the Saudi dissident Jamal Khashoggi, effectively blocking yet another effort to hold the kingdom’s leader accountable for the grisly crime.
articles.byline: By Ben Hubbard and Edward Wong

articles.headline: How FTX’s Sister Firm Brought the Crypto Exchange Down
articles.snippet: Alameda Research was Sam Bankman-Fried’s first company. He built FTX partly to help Alameda’s trading business. Then things got out of control.
articles.abstract: Alameda Research was Sam Bankman-Fried’s first company. He built FTX partly to help Alameda’s trading business. Then things got out of control.
articles.lead_paragraph: In late 2017, Sam Bankman-Fried, then 25 years old, co-founded Alameda Research, a small trading firm that marked the beginning of his cryptocurrency empire.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein, Alexandra Stevenson, Maureen Farrell and David Yaffe-Bellany
